name: monochloropentafluoroethane production, chlorofluorination of ethylene | hexafluoroethane | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/953/documentation

This dataset represents the chlorofluorination of ethylene. Ethylene chlorofluorination is one of the most important processes to produce monochloropentafluoroethane.The functional unit is 1 kg ethylene. The system includes the process with consumption of raw materials, energy, infrastructure, and land use, as well as the generation of emissions to air and water. It also includes transportation of the raw materials. Transient or unstable operations like starting-up or shutting-down, are not included, but the production during stable operation conditions. Storage and transportation of the final product are also not included. It is assumed that the manufacturing plants are located in an urban/industrial area and consequently the emissions are categorised as emanating in a high population density area. The emissions into water are assumed to be emitted into rivers. Within the chlorofluorination of ethylene, monochloropentafluoroethane and hexafluoroethane are derived as co-products.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From the reception of ethylene, chlorine and hydrogen fluoride to the factory gate.

This activity ends with the chlorofluorination of ethylene including materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for the world..
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In this dataset the Montedison chlorofluorination process is taken as the technology to produce monochloropentafluoroethane. It is a reaction of ethylene with chlorine and hydrogen fluoride which takes place in a single step in a fluidized-bed reactor. A suitable catalyst is a combination of aluminum chloride and other metals.;2 C2H4 + 10 Cl2 + 11 HF → C2ClF5 + C2F6 + 19 HCl;The hydrochloric acid is neutralized with sodium hydroxide.;Commercial production of chlorofluoroalkanes is also possible by the electrochemical fluorination process developed by Phillips Petroleum.;Impurities are usually removed from organic fluorine compounds by fractional distillation, fractional crystallization, or chromatographic methods. This does not apply to fluoropolymers and high-boiling perfluorinated oils, which require special measures, i.e., the use of extremely pure starting materials.;Quantitative determination of fluorine is possible in most cases by combustion and subsequent analysis of the hydrogen fluoride generated. Wet chemical methods are used to determine fluoride ions.;Because of the high volatility of organic fluorine compounds, purity can be readily determined by gas chromatography. 19F-Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy is a valuable tool for determining the structure of organic fluorine compounds. Structure determinations, even of mixtures, are often easier using this method than with 1H-NMR spectra due to the larger chemical shifts of 19F-NMR spectra. The 19F signals can be integrated and used for quantitative analysis.;Chlorofluoroalkanes (and also the alternative HCFCs and HFCs) produced on an industrial scale are subject to stringent standards. Impurities must not exceed the following limits: ;Siegemund, G., Schwertfeger, W., Feiring, A., Smart, B., Behr, F., Vogel, H., McKusick, B.: Fluorine Compounds, Organic. Published online: 2002. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/emrw/9783527306732/home
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Energy consumptions and emissions are estimated. Infrastructure and transports are calculated with standard values.

exchanges.description: Estimation. The remaining amount of unreacted chlorine (4.8 % of the input) and sodium chloride from the HCl neutralization is assumed to leave the production process with the waste water.

exchanges.description: Estimation. The ethylene emissions are incinerated to CO2 with a assumed destruction efficiency of 99 %.

exchanges.description: Estimation. The chlorine emissions are estimated to 0.2% of the input.

flow.name: Ethylene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE
Estimation. These values were approximated with data from an large chemical plant site in Germany producing 2.05 Mt a-1 (intermediates included) of different chemicals. The values for the energy consumption per kg of product of this plant (3.2 MJ kg-1) were used as approximation for the energy consumption of the chlorofluorination of ethylene. This total energy demand contains a split of 50% natural gas, 38% electricity and 12% steam from external energy sources.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Estimation. These values were approximated with data from an large chemical plant site in Germany producing 2.05 Mt a-1 (intermediates included) of different chemicals. The values for the energy consumption per kg of product of this plant (3.2 MJ kg-1) were used as approximation for the energy consumption of the chlorofluorination of ethylene. This total energy demand contains a split of 50% natural gas, 38% electricity and 12% steam from external energy sources. For this inventory all energy used for heat or steam was assumed to be natural gas.
